error_name: Initials Instead of Full First Name
description: Using initials for author names instead of full first names. This is likely confusion with APA style, which requires initials.
wrong_example: Morrison, T. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: MLA 9 requires full first names to provide clarity and respect for author identity. Students often confuse this with APA style which uses initials.
fix_instructions: Replace all initials with full first names
Check middle names - use full middle name or omit entirely
Verify spelling of author's actual first name
Never use just an initial for first or middle name

frequency.research_basis: APA style confusion - most common MLA error

prevention_tips: Remember: MLA = full names, APA = initials
Look up author's full name if unsure
Check book cover or article byline for full name

description: Using '&' instead of 'and' between two author names. This is APA style, not MLA.
wrong_example: Garcia, Maria, & Sanjay Patel. *Economics*. McGraw-Hill, 2019.
correct_example: Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel. *Economics*. McGraw-Hill, 2019.
explanation: MLA uses the word 'and' for formality and readability. APA uses '&' for brevity.
fix_instructions: Second author name should not be inverted
prevention_tips: Remember: MLA = 'and', APA = '&'
Spell out 'and' fully

error_name: Sentence Case Instead of Title Case
description: Using sentence case for titles instead of Title Case. This is likely confusion with APA style which uses sentence case for articles and chapters.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: MLA requires Title Case for ALL titles (articles, books, websites, etc.). APA uses sentence case for articles and chapters.
fix_instructions: Capitalize all major words (nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs)
Keep articles (a, an, the), conjunctions, and prepositions lowercase unless first/last

frequency.research_basis: THE most common MLA formatting error

prevention_tips: Remember: MLA = Title Case for everything
Check each major word for capitalization
Use title case converter if unsure

description: Using quotation marks for book titles instead of italics. Books are complete works and should be italicized.
wrong_example: Morrison, Toni. "Beloved." Knopf, 1987.
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: Complete works (books, journals, films) use italics. Shorter works (articles, chapters, poems) use quotation marks.
fix_instructions: Remove quotation marks from book title
Apply italic formatting to entire book title

frequency.research_basis: Confusion about which titles use which formatting

prevention_tips: Remember: Big = italics (books, journals), Small = quotes (articles, chapters)
Ask: Is this a complete standalone work?

description: Using italics for article titles instead of quotation marks. Articles are shorter works contained in journals and should use quotation marks.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. *Modern Storytelling.* *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: Shorter works (articles, chapters, poems, web pages) use quotation marks to indicate they are part of a larger container.
fix_instructions: Remove italic formatting from article title
Add quotation marks around article title
Period goes inside closing quotation mark
prevention_tips: Remember: Articles go IN journals, so they get quotes
Container (journal) gets italics, content (article) gets quotes

description: Placing publication date in parentheses after author name. This is APA style, not MLA.
wrong_example: Morrison, Toni. (1987). *Beloved*. Knopf.
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: In MLA, date comes after publisher in the publication sequence. APA places date after author for emphasis on currency.

frequency.research_basis: APA style confusion - major structural difference

prevention_tips: Remember: MLA date after publisher, APA date after author
No parentheses around dates in MLA

description: Capitalizing 'vol.' and 'no.' abbreviations as 'Vol.' and 'No.'. MLA requires lowercase.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, Vol. 4, No. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: MLA style uses lowercase abbreviations for volume and issue to maintain consistency with other abbreviations.
prevention_tips: Remember: lowercase vol. and no. in MLA
These are abbreviations, not proper nouns

description: Using APA's volume(issue) format like 4(2) instead of MLA's 'vol. 4, no. 2' format.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts* 4(2), 2022, pp. 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: MLA uses spelled-out abbreviations for clarity. APA uses compact parenthetical format.
fix_instructions: Spell out vol. and no. abbreviations
prevention_tips: Remember: MLA spells out vol. and no., APA uses parentheses
MLA is more explicit for readability

description: Omitting 'pp.' before page ranges in Works Cited entries.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: MLA requires 'pp.' before page numbers in Works Cited (but not in in-text citations). This clarifies what the numbers represent.
prevention_tips: Remember: Works Cited = pp., In-text = no pp.
Always include pp. before ranges in Works Cited

description: Including city or place of publication before publisher. This was required in MLA 8 but removed in MLA 9.
wrong_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. New York: Knopf, 1987.
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: MLA 9 simplified book citations by removing place of publication, which is no longer relevant in digital age.
prevention_tips: Remember: MLA 9 dropped place of publication
Go straight to publisher name

description: Including http:// or https:// in URLs. MLA requires omitting the protocol for simplicity.
wrong_example: Lee, Michael. "Climate Trends 2024." *Eco Report*, 5 Feb. 2024, https://www.ecoreport.org/climate2024.
correct_example: Lee, Michael. "Climate Trends 2024." *Eco Report*, 5 Feb. 2024, www.ecoreport.org/climate2024.
explanation: MLA simplifies URLs by removing unnecessary technical details. Protocol is assumed.
fix_instructions: Start URL with domain (www. or direct domain)
prevention_tips: Remember: No http:// or https:// in MLA URLs
Exception: DOIs keep https://doi.org/ prefix

description: Using 'n.d.' when publication date is unavailable. MLA simply omits the date element.
wrong_example: Author, Name. "Title." *Website*, n.d., www.example.com.
correct_example: Author, Name. "Title." *Website*, www.example.com.
explanation: MLA 9 doesn't use placeholders like 'n.d.' - if information is unavailable, omit that element.
fix_instructions: Consider adding access date if no publication date
prevention_tips: Remember: MLA = omit if missing, APA = use 'n.d.'
Don't use placeholders in MLA

description: Inverting the second author's name in a two-author citation. Only the first author's name should be inverted.
wrong_example: Garcia, Maria, and Patel, Sanjay. *Economics*. McGraw-Hill, 2019.
correct_example: Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel. *Economics*. McGraw-Hill, 2019.
explanation: In MLA, only the first author's name is inverted for alphabetization. Subsequent authors use normal (First Last) order for readability.
fix_instructions: Change second author to normal order (First Last)
Remove comma after second author's last name if present

frequency.research_basis: Logical assumption that all authors follow same pattern

prevention_tips: Remember: First author inverted, others normal
Only invert for alphabetization (first author)

description: Omitting the final period at the end of the citation.
wrong_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: Every MLA citation must end with a period, regardless of what element ends the citation (URL, page number, date, etc.).
fix_instructions: Add period at the very end
Check that it comes after the final element
prevention_tips: Always end with a period
Double-check final punctuation

error_name: Editor Name Inverted in Chapter Citation
description: Inverting editor names (Last, First) in book chapter citations. Editor names should be in normal order (First Last) after 'edited by'.
wrong_example: Harris, Muriel. "Talk to Me." *A Tutor's Guide*, edited by Rafoth, Ben, Heinemann, 2000, pp. 24-34.
correct_example: Harris, Muriel. "Talk to Me." *A Tutor's Guide*, edited by Ben Rafoth, Heinemann, 2000, pp. 24-34.
explanation: In MLA, contributor names (editors, translators, directors) after 'edited by', 'directed by', etc. use normal order (First Last), not inverted.
fix_instructions: Change editor name from (Last, First) to (First Last)
Use normal order for all editors
Can use 'et al.' for multiple editors

frequency.research_basis: Logical assumption that all names follow same pattern

prevention_tips: Remember: Author inverted, contributors (editors/directors) normal
Names after 'edited by' or 'directed by' use normal order

description: Listing more than one author before 'et al.' when there are three or more authors.
wrong_example: Nickels, William, Smith, John, et al. *Business*. McGraw-Hill, 2016.
correct_example: Nickels, William, et al. *Business*. McGraw-Hill, 2016.
explanation: MLA simplifies three-or-more author citations by using only the first author's name followed by 'et al.'
prevention_tips: Remember: 3+ authors = first author only + et al.
Don't list additional authors before et al.

error_name: Both Quotation Marks and Italics on Title
description: Using both quotation marks AND italics on the same title. This is redundant and incorrect.
wrong_example: Morrison, Toni. *"Beloved"*. Knopf, 1987.
correct_example: Morrison, Toni. *Beloved*. Knopf, 1987.
explanation: Titles use either quotation marks (shorter works) or italics (complete works), never both.
fix_instructions: Determine if work is short or complete
prevention_tips: Choose one: quotes OR italics, never both
Ask: Is it a part of something (quotes) or standalone (italics)?

description: Using American Month-Day-Year format instead of MLA's Day-Month-Year format.
wrong_example: Lee, Michael. "Climate Trends." *Eco Report*, Feb. 5, 2024, www.ecoreport.org.
correct_example: Lee, Michael. "Climate Trends." *Eco Report*, 5 Feb. 2024, www.ecoreport.org.
explanation: MLA uses European-style Day-Month-Year format without commas for international consistency.

frequency.research_basis: American date format is default for US students

prevention_tips: Remember: MLA uses Day Month Year (no commas)
Think European date format

description: Including 'p.' or 'pp.' before page numbers in parenthetical in-text citations. MLA in-text citations omit this.
wrong_example: (Morrison, p. 42)
correct_example: (Morrison 42)
explanation: MLA in-text citations are simplified - just author last name and page number, no 'p.' or comma.
fix_instructions: Remove comma between author and page
Keep space between author and page number

frequency.research_basis: Confusion with Works Cited format or APA style

prevention_tips: Remember: In-text = (Author Page), Works Cited = pp. pages
No 'p.' or comma in in-text citations

description: Using quotation marks for journal titles instead of italics. Journals are containers and should be italicized.
wrong_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." "Journal of Modern Arts", vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
correct_example: Khan, Samira. "Modern Storytelling." *Journal of Modern Arts*, vol. 4, no. 2, 2022, pp. 45-58.
explanation: Containers (journals, magazines, websites) are always italicized. Only the article title uses quotation marks.
fix_instructions: Remove quotation marks from journal title
Apply italic formatting to journal title
Keep article title in quotation marks
prevention_tips: Remember: Containers always italic (journals, websites, books)
Contents use quotes (articles, chapters)
